awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: On the ground and from above: A multi-factor analysis of the direct and indirect drivers of tallgrass prairie small mammal communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Doctoral Dissertation Research: On the ground and from above: A multi-factor analysis of the direct and indirect drivers of tallgrass prairie small mammal communities

This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement project investigates the role of both broad-scale land cover and small-scale management activities in driving the populations of small mammals, such as mice in voles in tallgrass prairies. Tallgrass prairies provide critical ecosystem services such as carbon storage, cultural connections, and water retention. By building our understanding of prairie food webs, we aim to equip land managers with a more complete picture to inform management decisions. Furthermore, this study contributes to the knowledge about complex prairie ecosystems and management effects across multiple scales. On broader impacts, this study 1)trains dozens of volunteers, including undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds, on small mammal trapping methodology, 2) provides support for land managers aiming to make evidence-based management decisions, and 3) develops and implements a lesson in landscape ecology for use in undergraduate classrooms. 

The multi-scale drivers of small mammal populations are not currently well-understood, especially in critically threatened tallgrass prairie habitats. To better understand these complex systems, this study uses long-term small mammal trapping data, long-term vegetation surveys, and land cover data derived from drone imagery to examine how land cover and management activities shape small mammal populations, directly or indirectly, through impacts on vegetation. Due to their central role in prairie food webs, understanding small mammal populations helps decipher the community's health as a whole. By analyzing the drivers of these species, this work advances the knowledge about prairie communities and the impacts of habitat change and management activity, especially in the wake of human activities that may degrade or restore the ecosystem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In order to gain a better understanding the multiple spatial and management factors that impact small mammals in tallgrass prairies, we combined spatial analysis with ten years of small mammal trapping data.

Using a large-scale prairie restoration site, we evaluated the impacts of land cover at small and medium scales, as well as the effects of management activities like prescribed fire and reintroduced large grazers. We employed drone imagery and classification of land cover to assess the impacts of habitat fragmentation that is characteristic of many restoration projects. We identified direct impacts of land cover and management on small mammals, as well as indirect impacts via effects on the vegetative community.

Our findings help provide a greater understanding of the far-reaching impacts of land management. We measured management activities like prescribed fire and bison grazing using quantitative measures as opposed to the standard categorical classifications of presence and absence, and found that this was an effective strategy that revealed new impacts. We also reaffirmed the importance of assessing land cover impacts on small mammal communities.

 

The intellectual merit outcomes of our project included:

Two published manuscript and one manuscript in preparation

One doctoral dissertation published

New information regarding the indirect role of management activities in shaping small mammal communities.

Analysis incorporating quantitative measures of management activities in addition to standard categorical metrics.

 

The broader impact outcomes of our project included:

2 conference presentations

Outreach presentations to nearly 100 K-12 students from schools across the United States.

3 students trained in science techniques and communication (1 graduate student, 2 undergraduate students)

Over 50 volunteers trained in scientific data collection, many of whom are undergraduate students with no previous research experience.

Collaboration with managers at the research site, and thus direct delivery of results that are being used to inform future management strategies

Outreach to hundreds of members of the public through outreach presentations


Last Modified: 10/31/2024
Modified by: Erin G Rowland-Schaefer
